text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

IRM 1.15.5.3 - Transferring to a New Business Unit/Organization - Added new subsection and content on records responsibilities when transferring to a new Business Unit/Organization. Following this newly added IRM subsection, the remaining subsections have been renumbered accordingly.

IRM 1.15.5.10.1 - Employee/Manager Roles and Responsibilities (Outside HR Connect) - Updated content on records-related responsibilities prior to separation. Also added content on the to complete/submit Form 14757 , Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, on separating Interns, Volunteers, and Student Trainees (paid or unpaid). Subsection has been renumbered.

IRM 1.15.5.10.2 - Employee Responsibilities Regarding Personal Documents - Changed the Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) mailbox address for submitting Form 14757, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees. Subsection has been renumbered.

IRM 1.15.5.10.3 - Documents Which Can Be Removed - Changed the Separating Employee Clearance mailbox address for submitting Form 14757 , Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees. Subsection has been renumbered.

1.15.5.10.5 - Separating Employees Checklist (Form 14757) - Clariﬁed instructions for 14757 , Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees. Changed the Clearance (SEC) mailbox address for submitting Forms 14757 to the SEC Records group. Also added the requirement for Form 14757 to be completed/submitted on Interns, Volunteers, and Student Trainees (paid or unpaid). Subsection has been
) IRM
- Exceptions to Use of Form
for Separating Employee Clearance - the Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) mailbox for submitting the
-day Temporary Appointment Employee Termination list to the SEC Records Advisors group. Subsection has been renumbered. (
) IRM
- Retention of Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) Records - Changed the retention period for Form
from ten (
) years to three (
) years in accordance with updated NARA guidance. (
) IRM references, website links, and editorial updates have been made throughout this IRM section.
IRM 1.15.5.10.6 - Retention of Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) Records - Changed the retention period for Form 14757 from ten (10) years to three (3) years in accordance with updated
IRM references, website links, and editorial updates have been made throughout this IRM section.

Penalties for Unlawful Removal, Alienation, or Destruction of Government Records
Records
page (

) Purpose: This IRM explains how to relocate records between offices and nizations, and release custody to another government agency, including the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). (

) This IRM also includes policy on IRS employees’ and managers’ responsibili- ties for ensuring Federal records are appropriately secured in advance of employee separation from the agency, including completion and submission Form

, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, to document that all Federal records with ongoing retention requirements have been properly secured, including safeguarding records subject to litigation holds. The completion and submission of Form
is also required on separating Interns, Volunteers, and Student Trainees (paid or unpaid). Note: Business Units are entitled to an exception from completing and submitting Form
, for their employees who work on
-day temporary pointments. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to ALL IRS employees and contractors. (

) Program Owner: The Records and Information Management (RIM) Program, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the Servicewide records management (
) Proper management of IRS documents (hard copy and electronic) improves business efficiency and timely responses to litigation and Freedom of tion Act (FOIA) requests. (
) This IRM provides guidance on removing personal documents, as well as venting the unauthorized removal of government records by IRS employees, including political appointees. (

) Guidance on the Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) process is included this IRM and integrates records management-related requirements into the Connect SEC maintenance record, under the Legal Category. The guidance outlines the records management responsibilities when separating from the Service, in compliance with NARA policies and helps ensure the IRS retains ﬁles in a recordkeeping system that supports ongoing records management and litigation requirements. (
) This IRM provides guidance on how to relocate records between offices and organizations, and how to release custody to another government agency, including NARA. (

) The Is It a Record? ﬂowchart provides the process in determining whether information you have (hard copy or electronic) is a record and actions you must take. Once you determine you have a record, review the information on What to do with a Record. Contact your Records Specialists or Business Unit (BU) Information Resource Coordinator (IRC) with questions and for assistance. (
) The

Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Chapter XII, Subchapter B - Unlawful or Accidental Removal, Defacing, Alteration, or Destruction of Re- cords, is supported by the SEC process that helps ensure documents ing IRS information belonging to separated employees will be retained in a recordkeeping system that supports records management and litigation Internal Revenue Manual

This IRM also includes policy on IRS employees’ and managers’ responsibili- ties for ensuring Federal records are appropriately secured in advance of employee separation from the agency, including completion and submission of Form

, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, to document that all Federal records with ongoing retention requirements have been properly secured, including safeguarding records subject to litigation holds. The completion and submission of Form
is also required on separating Interns, Volunteers, and Student Trainees (paid or unpaid).

Guidance on the Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) process is included this IRM and integrates records management-related requirements into the Connect SEC maintenance record, under the Legal Category. The guidance outlines the records management responsibilities when separating from the Service, in compliance with NARA policies and helps ensure the IRS retains ﬁles in a recordkeeping system that supports ongoing records management and litigation requirements.
The
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Chapter XII, Subchapter B -

, Unlawful or Accidental Removal, Defacing, Alteration, or Destruction of Re- cords, is supported by the SEC process that helps ensure documents contain- ing IRS information belonging to separated employees will be retained in a recordkeeping system that supports records management and litigation
Records and Information Management
requirements. This includes the capability to identify, retrieve, and retain the documents for as long as they are needed.
This IRM is used by ALL IRS employees and contractors to ensure compliance with paper and electronic records management requirements.

) Following an organizational realignment, employees should: a. Relocate or migrate current records supporting the function to the new office or organization. b. Identify records not required by the new office or organization. Notify Records Specialists for possible retirement of these records to a Records Center (FRC). c. Notify the Records Specialists about the reorganization, which may re- quire revision of Document
, Records Control Schedules (RCS). d. Update the gaining or new office ﬁles plan to reﬂect the new and records. (

) Upon receiving a new position and/or before transferring to a new Business Unit or organization, employees must: a. Return records to an appropriate office location or give to the manager staff assuming recordkeeping responsibility. The transferring employee must ensure that the Business Unit can account for all records (paper and electronic) the employee maintained and possibly retired to a b. Identify records no longer required by the current office or organization, and notify the Records Specialists for possible records retirement to a FRC or process the Form
, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal, for ternal disposal of the records, if eligible. (
) NARA regulations,
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part

, of Records from the Custody of One Executive Agency to Another, prohibit release of records from one government agency to another without the ap- proval of the Archivist of the United States, unless any or all of the following conditions exist: a. Release or change in custody is required by statute, Executive Order (EO) or Presidential reorganization. b. Records are permanent and are eligible for transfer to NARA. c. Records are on temporary loan for official use. Reminder: Records subject to restriction upon their use, which is imposed by or by the agency, are still under restriction, even after they have released to the gaining agency. However, the restriction can be re-

a. Relocate or migrate current records supporting the function to the new office or organization. b. Identify records not required by the new office or organization. , Records Control Schedules (RCS). d. Update the gaining or new office ﬁles plan to reﬂect the new function(s) and records.
Upon receiving a new position and/or before transferring to a new Business Unit or organization, employees must:
1.15.5.3 (02-12-2021) Transferring to a New Business Unit / Organization

a. Return records to an appropriate office location or give to the manager or staff assuming recordkeeping responsibility. The transferring employee must ensure that the Business Unit can account for all records (paper and electronic) the employee maintained and possibly retired to a FRC. b. Identify records no longer required by the current office or organization, and notify the Records Specialists for possible records retirement to a FRC or process the Form
, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal, for in-
) NARA regulations,
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part

, of Records from the Custody of One Executive Agency to Another, prohibit release of records from one government agency to another without the ap- proval of the Archivist of the United States, unless any or all of the following conditions exist: a. Release or change in custody is required by statute, Executive Order (EO) or Presidential reorganization. b. Records are permanent and are eligible for transfer to NARA. c. Records are on temporary loan for official use.
(08-08-2017) Releasing Records Custody Between Government

Reminder: Records subject to restriction upon their use, which is imposed by EO or by the agency, are still under restriction, even after they have been released to the gaining agency. However, the restriction can be re- moved later with a written agreement between the agencies.
Records and Information Management

include documents related to policy, procedures, organization, or executive direction of Internal Revenue Service’s (IRS) activities; contain evidence of the organization and functions of the IRS; contain information useful for researching the administrative history of IRS and the Department of the Treasury; or are of value to the IRS because they contain information needed for or
ganizational, procedural, and policy decisions.
Note: See 36 CFR 1220.18, General Deﬁnitions, for the regulatory deﬁnition of “permanent” records.
Only original or official copies of records which meet the deﬁnition of permanent are required for archival or permanent retention.
The following classes of IRS permanent records will transfer directly to NARA. These types of records should not be retired to a FRC. They are:
a. audio-visual records (movies, photographs, tapes, etc.) b. maps, charts, etc. c. electronic records referred to in IRM
, Managing Electronic Records. IRM
provides speciﬁc instructions on transferring permanent records directly to NARA.
Note: If a permanent record has been retired to a FRC for temporary storage, the FRC will transfer the records to a facility within the National Archives at the appropriate time.
FRC will transfer the records to a facility within the National Archives at the appropriate time. (

) Records Specialists work with records custodians to provide the following permanent records information, which is required by Standard Form (SF) Agreement to Transfer Records to the National Archives of the United Exhibit

, including a box inventory or list and samples, if requested: a. record series or title b. date span of records—beginning and ending c. major and minor subdivisions, i.e., Information Technology, Office of the Chief Information Officer d. contact person—include telephone number e. RCS authority f. volume and format (paper, PDF, photograph) g. any restrictions, e.g. Privacy Act, IRC
, Classiﬁed h. ﬁnding aids or documents i. records’ current location

) Submit the above information, background materials and samples, if requested, to the IRS Records Officer for processing at *Records Management. The IRS Records Officer will prepare and forward the SF

NARA for approval. After approval, NARA will provide an approved copy to IRS Records Officer, who will retain an approved copy and send a copy back to the Records Specialist or BU representative who originated the request. (

) When boxing and transferring permanent records to NARA, standard storage boxes are required. Each box must include a detailed index listing the contents. This list must be provided to the IRS Records Officer for with the SF
; shipping directions will be provided to the Records (if transferring directly from the agency and not from the FRC) along with the copy of the approved request. (

) Secure every box with the Caution Permanent Record Tape speciﬁcally designed by PGLD Records and Information Management team. This tape ensures the containers are not disposed of before eventual transferring to NARA and provides easy identiﬁcation of permanent records containers if stored in business units or on site. See Exhibit

) When shipping the container(s) directly to NARA, the standard storage box inside a sleeve box to eliminate double wrapping each box in opaque paper, so that the tape or box is not visible. Ensure the to/from address is printed each sleeve and inside box, so that if the sleeve is damaged in transit, the can be identiﬁed and delivered. To order record sleeve boxes, orders may go directly to Columbia Container Corp.,
Union Avenue, Baltimore, MD

, Fax number:
RECORD STORAGE BOX SLEEVE - bundles of
, plus shipping costs. of a different vendor is acceptable, but note that sleeve boxes must be one quarter inch in diameter larger on all six sides of a standard FRC box. (

) The separating employee clearance process requires certiﬁcation that hard copy records have been returned to an appropriate office location, given to supervisor or staff assuming recordkeeping responsibility, and/or electronic Federal records stored on IT-issued equipment (laptop, ﬂash drive/thumb external hard drive or other removable media) have been secured prior to turning in equipment. This certiﬁcation includes a signed statement by the separating employee’s manager remitted to the IRS Records and Information Management Office. (
) Managing documents in appropriate recordkeeping systems ensures IRS is compliant with NARA records management regulations and policies. (

) IRS employees and managers must ensure Federal records and other hard copy and electronic documents in their possession with ongoing records retention or litigation hold requirements are appropriately secured in advance of separation from the agency and electronic media turn-in. a. IRS employees must maintain and dispose of Federal records in accor- dance with the IRS comprehensive Records Control Schedules (RCS), which comes from two sources: Document
for IRS program/ mission-critical functions and Document
for General Records Schedule administrative-related functions (see IRM
and IRM
). Internal Revenue Manual

(02-12-2021) Separating Employee Clearance (SEC)
IRS employees must maintain and dispose of Federal records in accor- dance with the IRS comprehensive Records Control Schedules (RCS), which comes from two sources: Document
for IRS program/ mission-critical functions and Document
for General Records Schedule administrative-related functions (see IRM
and IRM
Records and Information b. To help determine record status, refer to IRM

, Types of Records and Their Life Cycles, and the Is It a Record? ﬂowchart. c. Separating employee documents may also be subject to a litigation Regardless of the form in which they are kept, documents that are sub- ject to a litigation hold must be preserved while the litigation hold is in place. For additional information on whether an employee is subject to a litigation hold, contact Chief Counsel by telephone at (

, or by email at Litigation.Hold@irscounsel.treas.gov. d. Documents may also need to be preserved for other reasons, such as holds issued in connection with pending Congressional inquiries or dom of Information Act (FOIA) requests. e. All separating employees (including senior officials) must timely: • Collect hard copy records and return them to their appropriate office locations (i.e., centralized ﬁle cabinet) or to a FRC, for example, if “checked-out” from FRC storage. • Review all electronic ﬁles, including emails, word processing documents, spreadsheets, folders, etc. saved to a personal hard drive for Federal records or other material that must be preserved or main- tained, and move them to an accessible network storage location. messages identiﬁed as Federal records must be handled in with guidance provided in IRM

, Managing Electronic Records, and NARA-approved records retention schedules. Email records saved to the network will be auto-archived. • Remove passwords from password-protected ﬁles and folders that you manage. Note: Employees should not provide passwords or PIN numbers for any IRS systems (such as IDRS, RGS, etc.). • Review with their manager Form

, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, for manager’s certiﬁcation that all records (hard copy and electronic) have been returned/secured/saved an appropriate recordkeeping system (such as a Business Unit Share- Point site) for ongoing preservation or maintenance, or transferred to staff assuming responsibility for a matter (for example, a case ﬁle or project ﬁle). (

) Coordinate any ongoing records preservation or maintenance needs with IT, necessary. This could mean extra records storage needs in a recordkeeping environment backed-up by a server or via network, and/or the transfer of rights to that data. Employees must allow time to complete records-related re- sponsibilities, beginning the process as early as possible prior to separation. (

includes separating Interns, Volunteers, or Student Trainees, re- gardless of paid or unpaid position. This guidance does not apply to outside agency contractors separating from an agency contract and already follow procedures outlined in Form
, Contractor Separation Checklist. (

) Personal documents are of a private and unofficial nature, that pertain to ployee’s personal affairs. See IRM
, Types of Records and Their Cycles, Personal Documents, for additional information on personal documents. (

) Employee responsibilities regarding personal documents are: a. Clearly identify and maintain those documents of a private or nature separately from the records of the office; and b. Remove personal information from documents containing both and business information; photocopy document and ﬁle the record without the personal information. (

) Personal documents may be removed at an employee’s discretion except when under a litigation hold. Senior Executive Team (SET) members, should consult with the IRS Records Officer at *Separating Employee ance (SEC) prior to removing personal documents to conﬁrm that such ments do not have an independent historical preservation interest. (

) An employee, leaving employment with the IRS, can remove certain non- record material: Can a. work aids, such as office diaries, logs, and memoranda of and telephone calls that are memorialized elsewhere by other, or detailed or complete records, provided the material does not contain national security, taxpayer privacy, or other conﬁdential information; b. extra copies of records (e.g. photocopies, etc.), unless prohibited or limited by, disclosure statutes, regulations, or agreements. (

) The conditions under which an employee can remove non-record material listed below: If removal does not Then Impose an administrative or Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s ﬁnancial burden approval to remove the material Violate the conﬁdentiality required Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s by national security, privacy, and approval to remove the material other interests protected by law Create a gap in the ﬁles and Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s affect integrity of the ﬁle, the approval to remove the material documentation, or the body of information Note: If separating employees want to remove copies of official records that be classiﬁed or otherwise restricted, they must ﬁrst consult the

a. work aids, such as office diaries, logs, and memoranda of conferences and telephone calls that are memorialized elsewhere by other, or more detailed or complete records, provided the material does not contain national security, taxpayer privacy, or other conﬁdential information; and b. extra copies of records (e.g. photocopies, etc.), unless prohibited or limited by, disclosure statutes, regulations, or agreements.

If removal does not Then Impose an administrative or Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s ﬁnancial burden approval to remove the material Violate the conﬁdentiality required Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s by national security, privacy, and approval to remove the material other interests protected by law Create a gap in the ﬁles and Obtain the IRS Records Officer’s affect integrity of the ﬁle, the approval to remove the material documentation, or the body of information

Note: If separating employees want to remove copies of official records that may be classiﬁed or otherwise restricted, they must ﬁrst consult the *Disclosure staff, Chief Counsel and the IRS Records Officer at *Separating Employee
1.15 Records and Information Management
The IRS, not the individual, is responsible for determining whether the release of potentially classiﬁed or restricted records is appropriate and under what conditions.
The conditions for which an employee CANNOT remove documents (record non-record, personal documents) are listed below:

If they are Then Covered by a litigation or other Do not remove hold because they are potentially relevant to a pending or contem- plated civil, criminal, or administrative proceeding, or a pending Congressional inquiry Note: Releasing the information would impair or prejudice the outcome of the pro- ceeding or otherwise adversely affect govern- ment policy, decisions, determinations, or other actions. National security information and Do not remove officially limited information Note: Such information remains classiﬁed, controlled or restricted, as long as required for national security or IRS’ interests.
Before an employee separates from IRS employment, the manager, per review with employees, must complete Form

, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, to certify the protection of Federal records, including the preservation of all documents (record or non-record) subject to litigation hold needs. After creating the Personnel Action Request (PAR) and processing the HR Connect SEC Record under the Legal Category SEC Items, the manager should sign and forward completed Form
to the Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) Records Advisors group using email address *Separating Employee Clearance (SEC).
) If the employee is not available due to death, adverse action, etc. the manager, to the extent possible, must complete Form
and notate in Block
of the form that the employee is not available. (
) Form
must be completed on separating Interns, Volunteers, Student Trainees, regardless of paid or unpaid position, even if a PAR action is not required in HR Connect. (
) Business units are entitled to an exception from completing and submitting Form
, Records Management Checklist for Separating Employees, for Use of their employees who work on

-day temporary appointments. temporary appointment employees do not utilize computers, but work in pipeline areas to open, sort, batch, and number mail/documents in a ing environment. They do not create, receive, or transmit federal records (in hard copy or electronic format). Note: This exception does not apply to employees in a non-work status as they are not permanently separated from the Service. When a separation occurs, Form
will be required for these employees. (
) To qualify for this exception, the employee must be on a
-day temporary appointment and must not create, receive, or transmit records (in hard copy or electronic format). If both criteria are met, the manager and employee are exempt from submitting Form
Note: If the employee’s

-day temporary appointment is amended, changed, updated, or altered to include the assignment of a computer or otherwise create, receive or transmit records, the exception is no longer plicable to the manager and employee. The records management outlined in IRM
, Employee/Manager Roles and Responsibilities (Outside HR Connect) is applicable and becomes effective. (
) Business units utilizing this exception authority will provide notiﬁcation to the Records and Information Management, SEC Records Advisors group via by the
th of each month to the *Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) box with the Subject line:
-day Temporary Appointment Employee Terminations, and include a list of the names and Standard Employee (SEID) numbers of the
-day terminations. (

) Business unit managers of the temporary appointment employee are required to access the Legal Category in HR connect and select “Not plicable” for the “Estimated Return Method” for both SEC Items (Form

CHKLST and Senior Executive Team (SET) Exit Brieﬁng). Managers must include a note in the “Comments” box: “Temporary Appointment Employee mination”. Any selection other than “Not Applicable” will require the manager submit Form
to the Records and Information Management office. (
) The Records and Information Management SEC Records Advisors group no later than the
th of each month following receipt of email notiﬁcation of termination of the
-day temporary appointment employee, process the SEC maintenance record in the HR Connect system to close out the transaction. (

CAUTION PERMANENT RECORD TAPEInstructionsArea Record Managers have been instructed to coordinate the identification ofpermanent records with local IRCs. To assist you after the permanentrecords have been identified. Records and Information Management Teamdesigned the enclosed (1) roll of tape1. Indicate with a permanent marker or a suitable ink that will not rub offthe Records Control Schedule on the line after RCS/. Please use the "CautionPermanent Record" (CPR) tape to seal the container(s).2. If the record is not easily identified as permanent records indicate byplacing a check mark in the box for possible permanent record, Area Records Managersshould review RCS/36 for identification of the records.The usage of the Caution Permanent Record tape will ensure that the containersare not disposed of before eventual transfer to NARA and provide easyidentification of permanent records containers if stored in business units or on site3. When shipping the container(s) to the Federal Records Center it issuggested to use filament tape under the CPR tape and a sleeve or box in a box tocover the wording "Caution Permanent Record"..
